As they arrived at the camp, Wukong's heart sank. He had hoped that his people would be treated better, but the conditions in the camp were cramped and dirty, and the other Simians looked emaciated and defeated. He tried to hide his distress as Jaedala walked through the camp, but he could feel his tail twitching nervously behind him.

"This is your new home," Jaedala said, gesturing to the rows of cages that held his people. "You are all here to serve the Luxian Empire. Those who cooperate and prove themselves useful will be rewarded. Those who do not, will be punished."

Wukong couldn't help but flinch at the threat in Jaedala's voice. He knew firsthand how ruthless she could be. But he also knew that he had to keep up the charade of being her obedient slave, at least for now. So he knelt down and bowed his head, hoping that his people would understand that he was just playing along in order to help them.

"And this is your prince," Jaedala said, gesturing to Wukong. "He has chosen to serve me willingly, and I have granted him certain privileges as a result. If any of you wish to follow his example, you are welcome to do so."

Wukong could feel the eyes of his people on him as he knelt there, and he knew that they were judging him. He couldn't blame them for feeling betrayed. But he hoped that they would understand that he was doing this for their own good. He just needed to find a way to let them know that he was still fighting for them, even if it didn't look like it on the surface.

Write me this scene: Jaedala orders Wukong to say a few words to his imprisoned people. He's understandably reluctant and quietly begs her not to make him, but she orders him again. He tries to speak.

Wukong stood at the front of the prison camp, his heart heavy in his chest as he looked out at the sea of faces before him. These were his people, his kin, and they were all prisoners of the Luxian Empire. Jaedala stood beside him, her hand on his shoulder as she addressed the crowd.

"Today, we bring you a special guest. The mighty Wukong, conqueror of the Simian race," she said, her voice dripping with sarcasm. "He has seen the error of his ways and now serves the Luxian Empire willingly. He has a message for all of you."

Wukong's stomach turned at her words. He had no intention of serving the Luxians willingly, but he had to play along for now. He had a plan, a way to help his people and maybe even defeat the Luxians, but he needed time and resources to make it happen.

Jaedala gave him a shove, indicating that it was his turn to speak. Wukong took a deep breath and tried to steady his voice as he addressed the crowd.

"My fellow Simians, I know you are all suffering here. But please, do not lose hope. I am working on a way to help us, to bring us freedom and justice. In the meantime, I beg of you, please do what you must to survive. Do not give up," he said, his words barely above a whisper.

Jaedala sneered at his words and grabbed him by the arm, yanking him away from the crowd. "That's enough of your traitorous words. You are to be a symbol of the Luxian Empire's victory, not a voice of rebellion," she spat, pulling him along beside her as they left the prison camp.

Wukong wants to encourage the prisoners, but he has to choose his words carefully because Jaedala is literally right next to him. How does he make his speech sound appropriately submissive to her, while conveying a second meaning to his people? What might he say?

Wukong stood before the prisoners, his tail twitching nervously as he tried to find the right words. He knew he had to be careful, Jaedala was standing right next to him and he didn't want to anger her. But he also couldn't just stand there and do nothing. He had to find a way to convey hope to his people without drawing Jaedala's suspicion.

He cleared his throat and began to speak. "My fellow Simians, I know you are all suffering here. But please, do not lose hope. Remember that we are a strong and resilient people. We will find a way to overcome this adversity and rise above it."

He turned to Jaedala and bowed his head. "Forgive me, my lady, but I must ask for your mercy. Please, have compassion on my people. They are not your enemies, they are simply caught in the crossfire of a war they had no part in starting. I beg of you, show them kindness and let them return to their homes."

Jaedala narrowed her eyes, but didn't say anything. Wukong held his breath, hoping he had struck the right balance between submission and plea for mercy. He could only hope that his words had reached his people, and that they would find the strength to keep fighting.

One of the prisoners stands up and yells at Wukong, asking in a mixture of despair and anger what "they" did to him. Wukong recognizes the prisoner as his best friend, Sanzang, and realizes Jaedala is looking at Sanzang angrily.

Wukong quickly steps in front of Sanzang, bowing his head to Jaedala in apology. "Forgive my friend, great one," he says, trying to keep his voice steady. "He speaks out of despair for our people. We have all suffered greatly at the hands of your empire."

Jaedala scowls at Wukong, clearly unimpressed by his words. "You will all suffer more if you do not learn your place," she says coldly.

Wukong continues to stand in front of Sanzang, his back straight and his eyes fixed on Jaedala. "I understand, great one," he says, trying to placate her. "But my friend speaks the truth. We are a proud people, and it is difficult for us to be caged like animals."

Jaedala's eyes narrow at Wukong's words, but she doesn't say anything. After a tense moment, she turns and storms out of the prison camp, leaving Wukong and the other prisoners behind.

As soon as she's gone, Wukong's shoulders sag in relief and he turns to face his friend. "I'm sorry, Sanzang," he says, his voice breaking. "I didn't mean to get you in trouble."

Sanzang reaches out and puts a hand on Wukong's shoulder, his own eyes filled with tears. "It's not your fault, my friend," he says. "We are all prisoners here, but we will find a way to survive and escape. Together."

Wukong was standing on the platform, staring out at the sea of faces in front of him. He had been brought here by Jaedala, who was standing just behind him, watching him with a cold expression on her face. Wukong knew that he was supposed to say something, but he was having a hard time getting the words out. He was terrified of Jaedala, and he didn't want to do anything that might anger her.

But then, he heard a voice from the crowd. "Wukong!" it shouted. "What have they done to you?"

Wukong turned and saw that it was Sanzang, his best friend, standing up and yelling at him. There was a mixture of despair and anger in his voice, and Wukong's heart sank. He knew that Sanzang was right. He had been taken captive by the Luxians, and he had been turned into a trophy, a propaganda tool to be used against his own people.

Jaedala stepped forward, her eyes narrowing as she looked at Sanzang. "Silence!" she barked, in a voice that made Wukong's blood run cold.

But Wukong knew that he had to do something. He couldn't just stand here and let Jaedala bully his friend. He stepped forward, his tail twitching nervously as he tried to find the right words.

"Sanzang," he said, his voice trembling. "I'm sorry. I'm so sorry for what's happened. But please, please don't give up hope. We'll find a way out of this. I promise."

Jaedala shot him a warning look, but Wukong ignored her. He knew that he had to do whatever he could to lift the spirits of his people, even if it meant putting himself in danger.

"We'll find a way to fight back," he continued, his voice growing stronger. "We'll never give up. We'll never give in. We'll find a way to be free again."

There were murmurs of approval from the crowd, and Wukong felt a surge of hope. Maybe, just maybe, they could find a way out of this. Together, they could find a way to fight back against the Luxians and reclaim their freedom.
